In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is planning a study entitled the Economics of 
Climate Change and Low Carbon Growth Strategies in Northeast Asia, covering the People's 
Republic of China (PRC), Japan, the Republic of Korea, and Mongolia. The Government of the 
Republic of Korea will cofinance the study. The project seeks to address climate change issues 
in these countries and suggest growth strategies aimed at achieving "green growth" and low 
carbon societies. The proposed study will capitalize on a similar study for Southeast Asian 
countries.1 The  objectives,  scope, implementation  arrangements,  and  financing plan  of  the 
technical assistance (TA) are reflected in this paper. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.    Asia  and  the  Pacific  are  experiencing  considerable  environmental  stress  as  a 
consequence  of  rapid  economic  growth.  The  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate  Change 
(IPCC)  estimated  that  developing  Asia’s  share  of  energy-related  carbon  dioxide  emissions 
increased from less than 9% in 1973 to 29% in 2005, and projected it will rise to 42% in 2030.3 
ADB’s Strategy 2020 addresses climate change as part of the broader strategic agenda of 
environmentally  sustainable  growth  in  developing  member  countries  (DMCs).4 One  of  the 
envisaged interventions is assistance to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through 
energy efficiency and renewable energy projects, while minimizing damage to the environment.  
 
3.  The effects of climate change are already apparent in Northeast Asia as demonstrated 
by rising temperatures. In Mongolia, a steady increase in temperatures has been observed over 
the past 60 years, with average temperatures rising by 1.8°C. As a result, the permafrost is 
degrading intensively and the melting of high mountain glaciers has increased. The PRC has 
experienced continuous warming during the past 50 years. Temperatures in Japan have risen 
about 1.0°C in the past century, with a 2.0°C–3.0°C rise in large cities. This increase is likely to 
exacerbate the phenomena of “heat islands” in countries such as Japan.5   
 
4.  The projected rise in sea level is likely to flood low-lying areas, affecting millions of 
people in Northeast Asia (footnote 3). The sea level is projected to be about 40 centimeters 
higher than it is today by the end of the 21st century.6 The maximum inundation area, for a 1-
meter sea-level rise with high tide and storm surge, is estimated to be 2,643 square kilometers 
(km2)—or about 1.2% of the total area of the Korean Peninsula.7 In the PRC, a 30-centimeter

sea-level rise would inundate 81,348 km2 of coastal lowland.8 In Japan, 861 km2 of coastal 
lowland is below the high water level, mainly in large cities such as Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya. 
A 1-meter rise in sea level is likely to put up to 4.1 million people at risk in the country.9 
 
5.  The increase in carbon dioxide emissions in Northeast Asia is likely to harm agriculture 
and other sectors. A doubling of carbon dioxide levels could decrease rice yields in many 
prefectures in central and southern Japan, even in irrigated lowlands, by up to 40%.10  
 
6.  The forest coverage area of broad-leaved Korean pines is projected to decrease by 
20%–35% with a significant shift north.11 In Japan, about 90% of the suitable habitat for a 
dominant  forest  species,  beech  tree  (Fagus  crenata),  could  disappear  by  the  end  of  this 
century.12 A northward shift of agricultural zones in eastern Mongolia is likely a result of climate 
change, i.e., the dry steppe zone is pushing the forest steppe north. This will shrink the high 
mountainous and forest steppe zones, while the steppe and desert steppe expand. Higher 
temperatures are likely to increase the frequency and aerial extent of the forest and steppe fires, 
which would reduce forest cover. In Mongolia, a significant decline in the forest cover could 
accelerate desertification, contributing to an increase in the frequency and intensity of dust 
storms and sandstorms.13 Countries such as Mongolia also face intensification of degradation 
and desertification because of shortages of water and precipitation.14 
 
7.  Northeast  Asia’s  vulnerability  to  climate  change  will  be  exacerbated  if  high  carbon 
economic development continues. Climatic vulnerability is already imposing an additional cost 
as existing patterns of preparedness (e.g., physical infrastructure, organizational arrangements, 
work habits), especially in the PRC and Mongolia, are no longer matching the unfolding climatic 
circumstances. The overall picture therefore is that Northeast Asia is one of the regions that 
significantly and increasingly contributes to climate change, but is also being affected by it.15 
Thus, alternative ways of achieving development aspirations that lead to green growth and low 
carbon societies in Northeast Asia need to be found.

8.  ADB is in a good position to undertake this initiative for the following reasons: (i) ADB is 
already mainstreaming climate change in its core development operations under ADB’s Strategy 
2020 (footnote 4); (ii) the study will be a major knowledge product that ADB can offer to its 
DMCs; (iii) the Action Plan for Implementing ADB's Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy 
(2008) recommends that synergies be developed between disaster risk reduction and support 
for climate change adaptation, because integrating the two is likely to benefit both; and (iv) ADB 
has good working relationships and strong links with institutions involved in climate change 
issues, such as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), 
United  Nations  Environment  Programme  and  its  subregional  partners,  and  the  Global 
Environment Facility (GEF). In addition, because of the uncertainty regarding the extent of 
climate change in Northeast Asia and its impact, this TA will contribute to identifying climate 
change trends in Northeast Asia over the next decade and suggest policies for coping with and 
countering future climate change impacts. The TA will also be able to corroborate other studies 
on climate change and its impact in Northeast Asia. The proposed TA will coordinate with other 
ongoing  and  planned  climate  change  initiatives  in  the  participating  countries,  allowing  for 
country-based mutual feedback and orientation of specific activities. It will also build upon 
existing studies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The purpose of the TA is to (i) contribute to the regional debate on the economic costs 
and benefits of unilateral and regional actions on climate change mitigation and adaptation; 
(ii) raise awareness about the urgency of climate change challenges; and (iii) indirectly support 
government and private sector actions in the region for green growth and low carbon strategies. 
The TA will cover four ADB members: Japan, Mongolia, the PRC, and the Republic of Korea.  
 
10.  The proposed TA will build on ADB's successful The Economics of Climate Change in 
Southeast Asia: A Regional Review (footnote 1), and complement ADB's parallel studies of 
South Asia and the Pacific. Japan and the Republic of Korea are expected to conduct their own 
assessments of the economic impacts of climate change; the study will mostly assimilate this 
information or place it in the regional context. In the PRC, the designated national authority—the 
Department of Climate Change, National Development and Reform Commission—is expected 
to prepare an assessment, and the ADB study can draw on the available information and 
analysis.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA’s impact will enhance resilience to climate change risks in Northeast Asia. The 
outcome of the TA will improve understanding of the economics of climate change to enable 
policy makers in Northeast Asia to initiate mitigation and adaptation actions.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The proposed TA has four phases with corresponding outputs and activities, as follows: 
 
(i)  Phase I: Scoping and review. This phase will involve mapping and assessing 
the current climate policy and adaptation measures at the country and regional 
levels in terms of their impact on different sectors and segments of population; 
and options and costs to address climate change issues. It will also identify 
(a) policy  gaps,  and  vulnerable  areas  and  sectors;  (b)  socioeconomic  and 
poverty impacts; (c) implications of climate change for poverty reduction and

4   
sustainable  development  efforts;  (d)  laws,  agreements,  or  regulations 
implemented, adopted, proposed, or in preparation that address adaptation to 
climate change; and (e) regional, national, or local initiatives on climate change 
issues. This phase will cover work carried out by governments, international 
organizations, academics, and nongovernment organizations. The result of the 
mapping and assessment activities will form part of the project interim report. 
 
(ii)  Phase II: Analysis of climate change. This phase will involve preparation of 
country-specific marginal abatement cost curves to analyze the GHG mitigation 
potential of technology options. An assessment of future climate change impacts 
on  major  sectors,  including  agriculture,  forest,  water,  marine  and    coastal 
resources (including fisheries), and health, at the regional and country levels will 
be conducted based on the outputs from the models under the IPCC climate 
scenarios. The analysis will be made by applying an integrated assessment 
model. Based on the regional and country impact assessment, climate mitigation 
and adaptation policies and measures will be formulated for the participating 
countries and the region. These will be some of the highlights of the project 
interim report.  
 
(iii)  Phase III: Climate policy simulation. A climate policy simulation tool (CPST) 
will be developed that will be used to generate key economic indicators to show 
the economic consequences of different packages of climate policies. It will also 
be used to conduct quantitative and qualitative assessments of different climate 
policy  packages.  The  CPST,  a  consolidated  model,  is  comprised  of  three 
components: (a) adaptation and impact assessment; (b) low carbon options; and 
(c) climate policy package. 16 The CPST will help policy makers select climate-
related policies with concrete economic consequences of climate policy choices 
and to strengthen the policy analysis related to the economics of climate change.  
 
(iv)  Phase IV: Dissemination. The final report will cover activities undertaken in the 
first three phases of the TA project. The TA results will be disseminated at the 
UNFCCC Conference of Parties 16, and the final TA results and findings will be 
communicated  through  participation  in  key  multilateral  events,  including  the 
Conference of Parties 17. The results of the project will also be disseminated 
through publication of articles in external journals and books, postings on the 
ADB website, coverage by international and national media, and presentations at 
conferences and workshops. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1.8 million, of which the equivalent of 
$1 million  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB‘s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund 
(TASF—others)  and  the  equivalent  of  $800,000  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the 
Government of the Republic of Korea and administered by ADB.17 The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                 
16 The CPST will cost $600,000. Component (a) will receive $200,000 in funding from the proposed regional policy 
and advisory TA for Regional Economics of Climate Change in South Asia Part II: Adaptation and Impact 
Assessment.  Components (b) and (c) will be funded under this TA and will cost $400,000. The development of the 
CPST will be a joint initiative of both TA projects. 
17 Through the Korea International Cooperation Agency.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. Within ADB, the East Asia Department will 
implement  the  TA  in  close  coordination  with  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department.  The  TA  project  will  use  a  two-tiered  management  structure.  A  study  team, 
comprising  national  climate  experts  from  the  participating  countries  and  international 
consultants, will be formed to carry out the TA activities. A team leader will be appointed from 
among ADB staff. A steering committee, which will act as the project executive, will set the 
methodological  and  strategic  directions  of  the  TA.  The  committee  will  comprise  senior 
government officials from all the participating countries and representatives from ADB and 
international organizations, such as the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for 
Asia and the Pacific, to ensure full participation and ownership of the project by the participating 
countries. Before commencing or financing activities under this technical assistance in the 
territory of a member country, written no-objection will be obtained from the country concerned. 
 
15.  The TA will require 41 person-months of international consulting services and 80 person-
months of national consulting services. A combination of individual consultants and a firm will be 
engaged to fulfill the requirements of the TA. A firm will be recruited using quality- and cost-
based  selection  with  a  simplified  technical  proposal.18 ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2008). The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  The  TA  is  expected  to  be  implemented  over  24  months  from  December  2009  to 
November 2011. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the Republic of Korea, and (ii) ADB providing 
the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for Economics of 
Climate Change and Low Carbon Growth Strategies in Northeast Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
 
                                                 
18 The CPST will have three contract packages. The component (a) will be engaged under the proposed TA for 
Regional Economics of Climate Change in South Asia Part II: Adaptation and Impact Assessment, while the 
remaining components (b) and (c) will be engaged under this TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Lead consultant (8 person-months, intermittent). The lead consultant will have extensive 
knowledge and experience in climate change issues and modeling, and a working knowledge of 
the adaptation and impact analysis of climate change and scenario building. A minimum of 10 
years experience in climate change fields is required. The successful candidate will 
(i)  under the direction of the team leader, manage and supervise the climate modeling 
specialist,  climate  change  economic  and  policy  analyst,  sector  adaptation 
specialists,  national  climate  experts,  research  analyst  and  project  coordinator—
collectively, the study team—and all activities under the technical assistance (TA); 
(ii)  undertake the scoping, mapping, assembly, and review of existing regional and 
country-level  climate  studies,  including  work  carried  out  by  governments, 
international institutions, academic institutions, and nongovernment organizations;  
(iii)  prepare and finalize an inception report; 
(iv)  organize and lead the regional consultations and national expert workshops and 
other meetings, consultations, and workshops as part of the TA; 
(v)  develop climate policy scenarios and options under each climate change scenario in 
coordination with the participating countries; 
(vi)  formulate policy directions and recommendations based on the cost and benefit 
analysis; 
(vii)  prepare  interim  and  final  reports  that  include  the  summary  outcome  of  the 
consultations  and  analysis  of  the  model  outputs,  and  manage  the  subsequent 
dissemination of the outputs; and 
(viii)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader. 
 
2.  Climate  modeling  specialist  (12  person-months,  intermittent).  The  climate  modeling 
specialist will have extensive knowledge and experience in climate change modeling. A minimum 
of 8 years work experience with a master’s degree in climate change modeling are required. The 
successful candidate will 
(i)  assemble  and  review  pertinent  energy-  and  non-energy-related  information  and 
other basic economic data for the participating countries to be used for the energy 
model structures; 
(ii)  provide  and  make  available  a  climate  impact  model  with  full  documentation, 
including  the  assumptions  made,  the  basis  for  the  assumptions,  the  data 
requirements, and data formats; 
(iii)  identify the level of adaptive capacity within the participating countries based on 
current ability to manage extreme weather events and existing climate variability at 
the macro and micro levels; 
(iv)  analyze the impact  based on a well-established regional climate impact model, 
investigating specific effects on different sectors; 
(v)  prepare a formal report on the analysis of an energy and non-energy model under 
different  climate  change  scenarios,  and  present  the  same  during  the  regional 
consultations, as may be necessary;  and  
(vi)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader and 
the lead consultant. 
 
3.  Climate  change  economic  and  policy  analyst  (6  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
climate  change  economic  and  policy  analyst  will  have  extensive  knowledge  and  expertise  in

current  trends,  policy  interventions  made  including  sector-specific  policy 
interventions, and pending policy legislation and recommendations; 
(iii)  attend the respective national expert workshop and the two regional consultations 
meetings; 
(iv)  provide data necessary for input to the integrated assessment model; 
(v)  assist in formulating country-specific climate policy packages; 
(vi)  assist in the identification of the level of adaptive capacity within the country based 
on current ability to manage extreme weather events and existing climate variability; 
(vii)  present the report, findings, and outputs during the national expert workshops; 
(viii)  provide other related country-level data and assistance to the team leader and lead 
consultant, as necessary;  
(ix)  prepare the national workshop report; and 
(x)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader and 
the lead consultant. 
 
6.  Project  coordinator  (12  person-months,  intermittent).  The  project  coordinator  will  be 
mainly responsible for the overall coordination, consolidation, and monitoring of various activities 
under the TA. A minimum of 5 years work experience with working knowledge on climate change is 
required. The successful candidate will 
(i)  prepare summaries of proceedings of all the regional and national workshops and 
meetings, in coordination with the study team; 
(ii)  compile, review, comment on, and edit consultants' reports of the regional and 
national experts workshop meetings, as required; 
(iii)  prepare background papers, briefing papers, presentation materials for meetings, 
workshops, and other TA-related events, as necessary;  
(iv)  prepare and submit a formal report on the cumulative outcome of the regional 
meetings and national experts workshops;  
(v)  participate in and assist in the TA workshops, seminars, and meetings; and 
(vi)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader and 
the lead consultant. 
 
7.  Research analysts (2 analysts, 9 person-months each for a total of 18 person-months, 
intermittent). The research analysts will be under the direction and supervision of the team leader 
and lead consultant. A minimum of 5 years work experience with a master’s degree in relevant 
fields are required. The successful candidate will 
(i)  assist  the  lead  consultant  in  undertaking  the scoping,  mapping,  assembly,  and 
review of existing regional and country-level climate change studies, including work 
carried out by governments, international institutions, academic institutions, and 
nongovernment organizations;  
(ii)  provide inputs and assist the lead consultant in preparing and finalizing the inception, 
interim, and final report;  
(iii)  gather data and conduct analysis, as directed by the team leader and the lead 
consultant, on the technical indicators necessary for the climate change impact 
modeling, and maintain all technical databases for the participating countries; and 
(iv)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader and 
the lead consultant. 
 
8.  Project assistant (18 person-months, intermittent). The project assistant will be under the 
direction and supervision of the team leader. A minimum of 5 years work experience is required. 
The successful candidate will

(i)  support  the  study  team  by  liaising  with  participating  countries  regarding  TA 
implementation  matters,  including  organizing  workshops  and  meetings  in  close 
collaboration with internal and external stakeholders;  
(ii)  facilitate the appropriate protocol required for events and coordinate all the required 
logistical arrangements for the conduct of the TA events (conferences, meetings, 
workshops, visits), including venue and travel arrangements, disbursements or per 
diem to participants, and liquidation of expenses;  
(iii)  assist the study team in the preparation of  workshop-related materials, maintaining 
a  database  to  record  responses  received  from  participating  countries,  making 
arrangements  with  resident  missions  or  other  government  focal  persons,  and 
acknowledging all responses received; 
(iv)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA as may be assigned by the team leader and 
the lead consultant.
